title: Sample Retention
legalBasis: Royal Decree 3484/2000 on hygiene standards for food preparation and sale; Regional regulations on collective catering and sample retention requirements; General food safety management principles under EU Regulation 852/2004
summary:
Sample retention, also known as testigo alimentario or witness food samples, is a food safety practice required for certain food service establishments, particularly those serving large numbers of meals or vulnerable populations. The practice involves retaining a representative sample of each dish served, stored under appropriate conditions for a specified period (typically 72-96 hours), to enable investigation if a foodborne illness outbreak is suspected.

The legal requirement for sample retention varies by autonomous community and by type of establishment. While not all regions mandate sample retention for all food businesses, it is typically required for collective catering operations such as schools, hospitals, elderly care facilities, workplace canteens, and catering companies. Some regions also require sample retention for restaurants and events serving buffets or large group meals. Even where not legally mandated, sample retention is a prudent food safety practice that demonstrates due diligence and facilitates rapid outbreak investigation.

When properly implemented, sample retention enables health authorities to quickly identify the food source of an outbreak, determine the causative pathogen through laboratory analysis, and prevent further illness by removing contaminated food from service. For the food business operator, retained samples provide crucial evidence in outbreak investigations and can exonerate the establishment if analysis shows the suspect food was safe. The system requires minimal investment but delivers significant food safety benefits.
keyPoints: Sample retention is legally required for collective catering and may be required for certain restaurants and events depending on regional regulations
Representative samples (minimum 100-150g) must be retained for each dish or food item served
Samples must be stored in clean, sealed containers at refrigeration temperature (0-4°C) for minimum 72 hours
Each sample must be clearly labeled with dish name, date, time, and service period
Samples should be retained until the retention period expires, then discarded
Staff must be trained in correct sample collection, labeling, and storage procedures
Sample retention records should be maintained showing what was sampled and when
Retained samples must be available for health inspectors and used only for investigation if food poisoning is suspected

sections.heading: 1. Legal Framework and Applicability
sections.content:
The legal requirement for sample retention in Spain derives from Royal Decree 3484/2000, which establishes hygiene standards for food preparation and sale establishments. Article 6 of this decree addresses sample retention, though the specific requirements and applicability are further defined by regulations of the autonomous communities. This has resulted in some variation across Spain in which establishments must retain samples and for how long.

Generally, sample retention is mandatory for collective catering establishments (catering colectividades) including school kitchens, hospital food services, residential care facility kitchens, workplace canteens, and catering companies. Many autonomous communities also require sample retention for restaurants and hotels when serving buffets, banquets, or group meals. Some regions require sample retention for all food service establishments above a certain size threshold (e.g., serving more than 100 meals per day).

Food business operators should verify the specific requirements of their autonomous community. Requirements typically specify which establishments must retain samples, which foods must be sampled (usually all dishes served, particularly those not subsequently cooked by the consumer), sample size, storage conditions, retention period, and labeling requirements. Failure to maintain required sample retention can result in non-compliance notices and fines during health inspections.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Who Must Retain Samples
subsections.content:
Collective catering establishments are universally required to implement sample retention. This category includes any food service operation providing meals to a defined group or institution: school cafeterias, hospital and clinic food services, residential care homes (elderly, children, disability services), university dining halls, workplace canteens, military food services, and prison food services. The requirement applies whether food service is provided by the institution itself or by a contracted catering company.

For commercial restaurants and hotels, requirements vary by autonomous community. Some regions require sample retention for all table service restaurants. Others apply thresholds based on seating capacity (e.g., more than 50 seats) or number of meals served (e.g., more than 100 meals per day). Buffet service, banquets, and catered events often trigger sample retention requirements even in establishments not normally required to retain samples. Tour operators and event caterers must retain samples when providing meals to groups.

subsections.heading: 1.2 What Must Be Sampled
subsections.content:
All dishes and food items served should be sampled, with particular attention to ready-to-eat foods that will not be further cooked by the consumer. This includes appetizers, salads, cold meats and cheeses, main courses (both hot and cold components), side dishes, sauces and condiments served separately, desserts (particularly those containing cream or custard), and any buffet or display items.

Each distinct dish requires a separate sample. For a plated meal, each component (protein, vegetables, starch, sauce) is theoretically a separate sample, though in practice many establishments take a sample of the complete plated meal. For buffet service, each dish in the buffet requires a separate sample. Pre-packaged items served in original sealed packaging (e.g., individual yogurts, sealed juice boxes) do not typically require sampling as traceability is maintained through the packaging.

subsections.heading: 1.3 Retention Period and Storage Conditions
subsections.content:
Retained samples must be held for a minimum of 72 hours (3 days) from the time of service, though some autonomous communities require 96 hours (4 days). The retention period allows time for symptoms of foodborne illness to develop in consumers and for the initial stages of outbreak investigation. After the retention period expires, samples may be discarded as normal food waste.

Samples must be stored under refrigeration at 0-4°C throughout the retention period. Freezing samples is not acceptable as it may affect microbiological analysis if testing is required. A dedicated refrigerator or clearly designated section of a refrigerator should be used for retained samples to prevent confusion with food in production or sale. The storage area must be maintained at the correct temperature and included in daily temperature monitoring procedures.

sections.heading: 2. Sample Collection Procedures
sections.content:
Proper sample collection is essential for the system to function effectively. Samples must be truly representative of the food served to customers, collected using aseptic technique to avoid contamination during the sampling process, of sufficient quantity for potential analysis, and collected at the point of service to reflect the actual food consumed by customers including any time-temperature exposure during holding or display.

The process requires planning and systematic execution, particularly in busy service periods. Staff responsible for sampling must understand the importance of the procedure and be trained in correct technique. Sampling should be integrated into service procedures so it becomes routine rather than an afterthought. In large operations, a dedicated staff member may be assigned sampling duties during each service period.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Sample Size and Containers
subsections.content:
The minimum sample size is typically 100-150 grams per dish, which provides sufficient quantity for multiple microbiological tests if analysis is required. For liquid or semi-liquid foods (soups, sauces, beverages), 100-150 milliliters is appropriate. The sample should represent the food as served — for example, a sample of a composed dish should include all components in the proportions served to customers.

Samples must be collected into clean, food-grade containers with secure, leak-proof lids. Disposable plastic containers with tight-fitting lids are ideal and are inexpensive enough for single use. Containers should be appropriately sized for the sample — overly large containers waste refrigerator space, while overly small containers may not hold adequate sample volume. Clear or translucent containers allow visual inspection of the sample without opening the container.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Collection Technique
subsections.content:
Samples should be collected using clean utensils or gloved hands to minimize contamination during collection. The food handler collecting samples should wash hands thoroughly before beginning and use a clean serving utensil for each dish to prevent cross-contamination between samples. The sample should be transferred directly from the service dish or holding equipment into the sample container without intermediate handling.

For plated service, the sample should be collected from the same batch and at the same time as food being plated for customers, ideally from the service line or hot-holding equipment. For buffet service, samples should be collected when the buffet is first set up, representing the food before any customer contact. If buffet items are replenished during service, additional samples of replenishment batches should ideally be collected, though in practice many establishments sample only the initial setup.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Labeling Requirements
subsections.content:
Each sample container must be clearly and completely labeled with information necessary to identify the sample in a potential investigation. Required information includes: dish or food item name, date of service, time of service or service period (lunch, dinner), and optionally batch number or preparation date if the same dish is prepared multiple times. A permanent marker should be used to write directly on the container or on an adhesive label.

Labeling must be clear and unambiguous. Generic descriptions like 'main course' are insufficient — specific dish names are required (e.g., 'chicken breast with mushroom sauce', 'vegetable lasagna', 'Caesar salad'). The date should include day, month, and year to prevent confusion. If multiple services occur on the same day, include the service time or period. Labels must remain legible throughout the storage period — ensure marker ink does not smudge or fade when exposed to refrigeration condensation.

sections.heading: 3. Storage and Management of Retained Samples
sections.content:
Once collected and labeled, samples must be stored under appropriate conditions and managed systematically to ensure they remain viable for potential analysis and are discarded appropriately when the retention period expires. The storage system should make efficient use of refrigeration space while maintaining organization that allows rapid retrieval of specific samples if an investigation occurs.

A systematic storage and disposal procedure prevents the accumulation of excessive numbers of samples and ensures that the correct samples are available when needed. In high-volume operations, sample management can become complex — a school serving lunch Monday through Friday generates 5-15 samples per day, resulting in 15-60 samples in storage at any time if different menu items are served each day.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Dedicated Storage Area
subsections.content:
Samples should be stored in a dedicated refrigerator or in a clearly designated and labeled section of a refrigerator used for other purposes. Dedicated storage prevents confusion between samples and food in production, prevents accidental use of samples for food service, and facilitates organization and retrieval. The storage area must be clearly marked 'Retained Food Samples' or 'Testigo Alimentario' with a notice that samples are not to be used for any purpose except investigation.

The refrigerator or storage section should be of appropriate size for the volume of samples generated. Temperature should be monitored and recorded daily as part of routine refrigeration monitoring. The storage area should be organized systematically, for example by date or by meal service, to facilitate retrieval and disposal. Some establishments use separate shelves or containers for each day's samples, making it easy to identify and dispose of samples when they reach the end of the retention period.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Organization and Retrieval Systems
subsections.content:
A logical organization system enables rapid retrieval if health authorities request specific samples during an investigation. Common approaches include organizing by date (all samples from one date together), by meal service (breakfast, lunch, dinner), or by date and meal service combined. Samples should be positioned with labels visible to allow identification without handling every container.

Some establishments maintain a sample log — a simple record showing the date, meal service, dishes sampled, and number of sample containers. This log serves as an index enabling quick location of specific samples and provides evidence of a systematic sampling program. For large operations, particularly those using computerized production management systems, sample logs can be integrated into digital record-keeping with dates, dish codes, and sample locations recorded systematically.

subsections.heading: 3.3 Disposal Procedures
subsections.content:
Samples must be retained for the full retention period (typically 72-96 hours) then discarded. A systematic disposal procedure prevents accumulation of expired samples and ensures refrigerator space is used efficiently. The simplest approach is daily disposal: each day, remove and discard all samples that have reached the end of the retention period.

Disposed samples should be treated as food waste and discarded through normal waste management procedures. Sample containers can typically be discarded with general waste after contents are removed, though some establishments use recyclable or compostable containers and dispose accordingly. A record of disposal (e.g., notation in the sample log that samples from date X were discarded on date Y) provides evidence that the system is being operated correctly.

sections.heading: 4. Use of Samples in Investigations
sections.content:
The purpose of sample retention is to facilitate rapid investigation if foodborne illness is suspected. If customers or staff report symptoms consistent with food poisoning, health authorities may request retained samples for analysis. The laboratory can test samples for pathogenic bacteria, viruses, toxins, and chemical contaminants to identify the source and cause of the outbreak.

For the food business operator, retained samples are both an investigative tool and potential evidence. If analysis shows that retained samples were safe and did not contain the pathogen responsible for illness, this can exonerate the establishment and indicate that illness resulted from other causes (e.g., contamination after service, illness not related to the meal). Conversely, detection of pathogens in samples confirms the source and may indicate control failures that require corrective action.

subsections.heading: 4.1 When Samples May Be Requested
subsections.content:
Health authorities will typically request retained samples when investigating a suspected foodborne illness outbreak — defined as two or more people experiencing similar symptoms after consuming food from the same source. The investigation may be triggered by reports from ill persons, by healthcare providers who have treated patients with suspected food poisoning, or by the food establishment itself reporting that staff or customers have fallen ill.

Samples corresponding to the meal(s) consumed by ill persons during the incubation period of the suspected pathogen will be requested. For example, if patrons report vomiting and diarrhea beginning 24-48 hours after dining, samples from meals served 24-48 hours prior would be of interest. The specific samples requested will depend on what ill persons report eating. This underscores the importance of maintaining complete, accurately labeled samples with clear traceability to specific meals and service times.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Sample Handover Procedures
subsections.content:
If health authorities request samples, they should be handed over using a chain-of-custody procedure that documents when samples were collected, how they were stored, and when they were transferred to the investigating authority. The food business should provide a record showing the sample collection date and time, storage conditions and temperature log, and identification of the person who collected and stored samples.

Samples should be transferred in insulated containers with ice packs to maintain refrigeration temperature during transport to the laboratory. If the health authority collects samples in person, obtain a receipt or documentation of what samples were taken. If the establishment is asked to transport samples to a laboratory, maintain cold chain throughout transport and obtain confirmation of delivery. Photographic documentation of samples before handover can provide additional evidence of sample condition.

subsections.heading: 4.3 Interpretation and Follow-Up
subsections.content:
Laboratory analysis of retained samples can take several days depending on the tests required. Bacterial culture tests typically require 48-72 hours, while virus detection and toxin analysis may take longer. The health authority will interpret results in the context of the overall investigation, including clinical symptoms, epidemiological data, and environmental investigation of the establishment's food safety practices.

If samples test positive for pathogens, the food business should expect detailed questioning about food sources, preparation procedures, temperature controls, and staff health for the implicated dishes. Corrective actions will be required to address any control failures identified. The establishment may face enforcement action depending on the severity of the outbreak and the control failures identified. If samples test negative, this suggests either that the illness was not foodborne, that it resulted from contamination after service, or that the contaminated food was not among the items sampled — follow-up investigation will explore these possibilities.

sections.heading: 5. Training and Operational Integration
sections.content:
Sample retention is only effective if implemented correctly and consistently. This requires that all relevant staff understand the purpose and procedures, that sampling is integrated into service routines rather than treated as an optional extra, and that management provides oversight to ensure compliance. Training should address why sample retention is required, what dishes must be sampled, how to collect samples correctly, how to label and store samples, and what to do if health authorities request samples.

Operational integration means making sampling a standard part of service procedures. For example, in a school kitchen, sampling might be the designated responsibility of the kitchen supervisor who collects samples from each dish as it is placed into service. In a restaurant with buffet service, sampling might be performed by the chef as part of buffet setup. Clear assignment of responsibilities prevents sampling being overlooked during busy service periods.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Staff Training Requirements
subsections.content:
All food handlers involved in food service should receive basic training on sample retention as part of their food safety training. Training should explain the food safety rationale — that retained samples enable rapid outbreak investigation and can protect both public health and the business reputation. Staff should understand that sample retention is a legal requirement for certain establishments and a best practice for all food service operations.

Detailed training on sampling procedures should be provided to staff with designated sampling responsibilities. This training should be practical: demonstrate collection technique, practice labeling, explain storage organization, and review disposal procedures. Assessment can be conducted through observation — verify that the staff member can correctly collect, label, and store a sample. Documentation of training should be maintained as part of HACCP training records.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Assignment of Responsibilities
subsections.content:
Clear assignment of sampling responsibilities prevents the task being overlooked. In small establishments, the manager or head chef may be responsible for all sampling. In larger operations, responsibilities may be distributed: kitchen supervisors sample items produced in their section, service managers sample buffet items, and designated staff handle labeling and storage. Whatever the structure, it must be clearly documented and communicated.

Responsibilities should be documented in job descriptions or task assignment sheets. A sampling checklist for each meal service can ensure all items are sampled — the checklist might list all menu items for that service with checkboxes to confirm sampling and fields for the sampler's initials and time. This provides both a procedural guide and a record demonstrating compliance. The system should include backup assignments so sampling continues even when the primary responsible person is absent.

subsections.heading: 5.3 Monitoring and Verification
subsections.content:
Management should regularly verify that sample retention is being performed correctly. Verification includes checking that samples are being collected for all required dishes, that samples are properly labeled with all required information, that storage temperature is maintained correctly, and that samples are disposed of appropriately when the retention period expires. Verification can be incorporated into daily management checks — for example, the manager might verify each day that previous day's samples are correctly stored and labeled.

Periodic audits using a sample retention checklist provide more comprehensive assessment. The audit might check: adequacy of dedicated storage space, organization and labeling of samples, completeness of sampling (are all dishes from recent services represented?), accuracy of temperature monitoring records, and maintenance of sample logs or records. Audit findings should be documented and any deficiencies corrected promptly. Sample retention should be included in HACCP verification procedures and reviewed during internal and external audits.

sections.heading: 6. Practical Considerations and Problem-Solving
sections.content:
Implementing sample retention presents practical challenges, particularly in establishments with limited refrigeration space, complex menus with many dishes, or high-volume service. Solutions include optimizing container sizes to minimize storage space requirements, using dedicated sample refrigerators if budget permits, prioritizing sampling of high-risk foods if it is not practical to sample every item, and implementing rigorous organization and disposal systems to prevent sample accumulation.

Common problems and solutions include running out of refrigerator space (implement daily disposal, use smaller containers, prioritize high-risk items), forgetting to collect samples during busy service (use sampling checklists, assign clear responsibilities, make sampling part of service setup), inadequate labeling (use pre-printed labels with fields to complete, provide permanent markers at sampling station), and confusion between samples and food in production (use dedicated storage area clearly marked, use distinctively colored containers for samples).

subsections.heading: 6.1 Refrigeration Space Optimization
subsections.content:
Refrigeration space is often limited in food service operations. To minimize space requirements for sample retention, use appropriately sized containers — small containers (e.g., 150-200ml capacity) hold adequate sample volumes without wasting space. Square or rectangular containers use space more efficiently than round containers. Stackable containers with secure lids allow vertical storage. Organize samples systematically (e.g., using plastic bins or trays labeled by date) to maximize space utilization and prevent disorganization.

For high-volume operations, a small dedicated sample refrigerator may be a worthwhile investment. Undercounter or compact refrigerators designed for laboratory use are ideal and can be positioned near the service area for convenient access. The dedicated refrigerator should be included in temperature monitoring and maintenance schedules. If dedicated refrigeration is not feasible, clearly mark and reserve a section of an existing refrigerator for samples with signage indicating that samples are not to be used for any other purpose.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Simplified Systems for Small Establishments
subsections.content:
Small restaurants with simple menus can implement straightforward sampling systems. If the establishment serves a limited, consistent menu, create a standard sample collection checklist listing all dishes typically served. Each service, work through the checklist collecting samples of dishes that were served that day. Use a simple dating system — write the date on each container and discard all samples with dates older than the retention period.

For establishments serving only one meal service per day (e.g., lunch only), organization is straightforward: collect samples during lunch service, store clearly labeled by date, and discard after the retention period. For establishments with multiple services, use separate storage areas or containers for each service and label clearly (e.g., 'Monday Lunch', 'Monday Dinner'). The key for small establishments is simplicity — the system should be easy to understand and quick to implement without disrupting service.

subsections.heading: 6.3 Complex Operations and Large-Scale Catering
subsections.content:
Large-scale catering operations serving hundreds or thousands of meals face significant sample retention challenges due to the volume and variety of foods. These operations may benefit from digital sample logging systems integrated with production management software. Barcoded sample labels can facilitate tracking and retrieval. Some large operations use professional sample retention systems with dedicated refrigerated storage and automated inventory management.

For operations producing food at a central kitchen for distribution to multiple service sites, sampling should ideally occur both at the central kitchen (samples of food as produced) and at service sites (samples of food as served to consumers after transport and any reheating). This provides complete traceability if an outbreak investigation occurs. Coordination between central production and service sites ensures samples are collected, labeled, stored, and disposed of correctly at all locations. The complexity requires detailed written procedures, comprehensive staff training, and active management oversight.

checklists.title: Daily Sample Retention Checklist
items: All dishes served today have been sampled (check against menu or production list)
Each sample container holds adequate quantity (minimum 100-150g or ml)
All sample containers are properly sealed to prevent spillage or contamination
All samples are clearly labeled with dish name, date, and service time/period
Samples are stored in designated refrigerated area at 0-4°C
Refrigerator temperature has been checked and recorded
Samples from previous service periods are organized and easily identifiable
Samples that have reached end of retention period (72-96 hours) have been discarded
Sample log updated with today's samples (if log is maintained)
Any issues with sample retention procedures reported to manager

checklists.title: Weekly Sample Retention System Review
items: Sample storage refrigerator is clean and organized
Temperature monitoring records for sample storage are complete and show consistent compliance (0-4°C)
Sample labeling is clear and complete on all stored samples
No expired samples remain in storage beyond the retention period
Adequate supply of sample containers, lids, and labeling materials is available
Staff with sampling responsibilities are following correct procedures
Sample log (if maintained) is up to date and accurate
Any customer or staff illness reports have been documented and samples preserved if investigation required

checklists.title: Monthly Sample Retention Program Audit
items: Review sample retention procedures and verify they reflect current regulations and menu
Verify all staff with sampling responsibilities have received adequate training
Conduct spot-check verification of sampling compliance (all dishes being sampled?)
Assess adequacy of sample storage refrigeration capacity
Review temperature monitoring records for sample storage refrigerator
Check sample containers and labeling materials stock levels and reorder if needed
Review any food safety incidents or illness reports — were samples appropriately preserved?
Verify sample retention is documented in HACCP plan and prerequisite programs
Update training or procedures if any deficiencies identified
Document audit findings and corrective actions in HACCP verification records

bestPractices: Integrate sampling into service setup procedures so it becomes automatic rather than an afterthought during busy service
Use pre-printed labels or label templates to ensure all required information is consistently captured
Implement a simple, visual organization system (e.g., color-coded bins by day of week) to make retrieval and disposal foolproof
Photograph your organized sample storage system and display the photo in the storage area as a guide for staff
Include sample retention in daily management walkthroughs to verify compliance and reinforce importance
For high-risk items (dishes containing cream, eggs, seafood, or previously cooked and reheated foods), never skip sampling even if time is short
Treat sample retention as evidence of your commitment to food safety — show organized sample storage during health inspections
Periodically conduct a 'test retrieval' exercise where staff practice locating specific samples from past services to verify the system works

glossary.Collective Catering: Food service operations providing meals to defined groups or institutions such as schools, hospitals, residential care facilities, and workplace canteens
glossary.Chain of Custody: Documentation of sample handling that tracks who collected the sample, how it was stored, and when it was transferred to investigating authorities
glossary.Foodborne Illness Outbreak: Occurrence of two or more cases of similar illness resulting from consumption of a common food or meal
glossary.Incubation Period: The time between consumption of contaminated food and onset of illness symptoms, varying by pathogen from hours to days
glossary.Retention Period: The time period for which food samples must be stored, typically 72-96 hours, to allow for symptom development and outbreak investigation
glossary.Sample: A representative portion of food as served, retained for potential laboratory analysis if foodborne illness is suspected
glossary.Testigo Alimentario: Spanish term for retained food sample or witness food sample
glossary.Traceability: The ability to track the source, production, and distribution of food through all stages from supply to service
glossary.Representative Sample: A sample that accurately reflects the food as served to consumers, collected from the same batch and at the same time as food service
glossary.Aseptic Technique: Methods used during sample collection to prevent contamination that could affect analysis results
